description: Burglar alarm and intrusion detection installation

questions.question: What is the primary function of an intrusion detection system?
options: Detecting unauthorized entry and alerting appropriate parties
questions.explanation: Intrusion detection systems detect unauthorized entry attempts through sensors and alert occupants, monitoring stations, or authorities.

questions.question: What is a door/window contact?
options: A magnetic switch that detects when doors/windows open
questions.explanation: Door/window contacts use a magnet on the door and a reed switch on the frame. Opening the door separates them, triggering the alarm.

questions.question: What is a PIR motion detector?
options: Passive Infrared detector sensing body heat movement
questions.explanation: PIR (Passive Infrared) detectors sense changes in infrared energy (body heat) as people move through the detection zone.

questions.question: What is a glass break detector?
options: A sensor that detects the sound/vibration of breaking glass
questions.explanation: Glass break detectors listen for the specific acoustic signature of breaking glass (both low-frequency impact and high-frequency glass shattering).

questions.question: What is the control panel in an alarm system?
options: The brain of the system that processes sensor inputs and controls outputs
questions.explanation: The control panel processes all sensor inputs, controls sirens and dialers, manages arm/disarm states, and communicates with monitoring stations.

questions.question: What is a keypad used for?
options: User interface to arm, disarm, and program the alarm system
questions.explanation: Keypads allow users to arm/disarm the system with codes, view system status, program settings, and receive alerts.

questions.question: What does 'armed' mean in an alarm system?
options: System is active and will trigger alarm if sensors are violated
questions.explanation: When armed, the system monitors all programmed sensors and will trigger an alarm condition if any protected zone is violated.

questions.question: What is a zone in an alarm system?
options: A circuit connecting one or more sensors to the panel
questions.explanation: A zone is an input circuit on the alarm panel connected to one or more sensors. Each zone can be individually programmed for different responses.

questions.question: What is a monitoring station?
options: A central facility that receives alarms and dispatches response
questions.explanation: Central monitoring stations receive alarm signals 24/7, verify alarms, contact the customer, and dispatch police/fire as needed.

questions.question: What is entry/exit delay?
options: Time allowed to enter/exit without triggering alarm after arming
questions.explanation: Entry/exit delays give users time to disarm after entering or leave after arming without triggering the alarm.

questions.question: What is EOL (End of Line) supervision?
options: Using resistors to detect wiring tampering or faults
questions.explanation: EOL resistors at the sensor create a specific resistance. Any change (cut wire, short, tamper) changes resistance and triggers trouble or alarm.

questions.question: What is DEOL (Double End of Line) supervision?
options: Two resistors for three states: normal, alarm, and tamper
questions.explanation: DEOL uses two resistors to distinguish between normal (one resistance), alarm (different resistance), and tamper/trouble (third resistance state).

questions.question: What is a dual-technology motion detector?
options: Combines PIR and microwave/ultrasonic requiring both to trigger
questions.explanation: Dual-tech detectors combine PIR with microwave or ultrasonic. Both must detect motion to trigger, reducing false alarms.

questions.question: What is pet immunity in motion detectors?
options: Pets cannot set off the alarm
Design that ignores motion from animals up to certain weight
questions.explanation: Pet-immune detectors use lens design and signal processing to ignore motion from small animals (typically up to 40-80 lbs) while detecting humans.

questions.question: What is the difference between NC and NO contacts?
options: Normally Closed vs Normally Open sensor contacts
questions.explanation: NC (Normally Closed) contacts are closed when secure (standard for intrusion). NO (Normally Open) contacts are open when secure.

questions.question: Why are NC contacts preferred for security?
options: A cut wire causes alarm (fail-secure) rather than staying normal
questions.explanation: NC circuits show alarm when wire is cut (circuit opens). NO circuits would not detect a cut wire, creating a security vulnerability.

questions.question: What is a siren driver?
options: Device that generates siren tones and powers the speaker
questions.explanation: Siren drivers generate the audio tones (yelp, steady, etc.) and provide power to drive siren speakers for local alarm notification.

questions.question: What is a strobe light in alarm systems?
options: Flashing light for visible alarm notification
questions.explanation: Alarm strobes provide visible notification of alarm conditions, helpful for hearing-impaired persons and for locating alarming buildings.

questions.question: What is cellular alarm communication?
options: Using cellular network to transmit alarms to monitoring station
questions.explanation: Cellular communicators transmit alarm signals via cellular networks, eliminating dependence on phone lines that can be cut.

questions.question: What is IP alarm communication?
questions.explanation: IP communicators transmit alarm signals over internet connections, often faster and more reliable than traditional phone dialers.

questions.question: What is stay mode vs away mode?
options: Stay arms perimeter only; Away arms perimeter and interior motion
questions.explanation: Stay mode arms perimeter doors/windows but bypasses interior motion sensors so occupants can move inside. Away mode arms everything.

questions.question: What is a panic button/zone?
options: Manual alarm trigger for duress or emergency situations
questions.explanation: Panic buttons allow immediate manual alarm activation for emergencies (medical, fire, police duress) regardless of system arm state.

questions.question: What backup power is required for alarm panels?
options: Battery backup for continued operation during power outages
questions.explanation: UL-listed alarm systems require battery backup to operate during power failures, typically 4-24 hours depending on requirements.

questions.question: What is a trouble condition?
options: A fault requiring attention (low battery, communication failure, etc.)
questions.explanation: Trouble conditions indicate system faults that need attention - low battery, sensor trouble, communication failure, power loss, etc.

questions.question: What is cross-zoning?
options: Requiring two zones to alarm before triggering (reducing false alarms)
questions.explanation: Cross-zoning requires two different zones to alarm within a time window before triggering the main alarm, significantly reducing false alarms.

questions.question: What UL standard covers burglar alarm systems?
questions.explanation: UL 681 is the Standard for Installation and Classification of Burglar and Holdup Alarm Systems, covering installation requirements.

questions.question: What is UL certificate for alarm systems?
options: Verification that the installed system meets UL standards
questions.explanation: A UL certificate indicates the complete installation has been inspected and meets UL 681 or UL 827 requirements, often required by insurance.

questions.question: What is Grade A vs Grade AA alarm classification?
questions.explanation: UL classifications (Grade A, AA, B) indicate extent of protection - number of sensors, types, coverage, and monitoring requirements.

questions.question: What is encrypted wireless sensor communication?
options: Secure transmission preventing interception or jamming
questions.explanation: Modern wireless sensors use encrypted communication (AES, rolling codes) to prevent capture/replay attacks and improve security.

questions.question: What is alarm verification?
options: Multiple sensor confirmation or audio/video verification before dispatch
questions.explanation: Alarm verification requires additional confirmation (second sensor, audio, video) before dispatch, reducing false alarm dispatches.

questions.question: What is SIA Contact ID format?
options: A standard digital communication protocol for alarm signals
questions.explanation: SIA Contact ID is an industry-standard protocol for transmitting alarm signals from panels to monitoring stations, providing event codes and zone information.

questions.question: What is zone swinger shutdown?
options: Automatic bypass of zone after multiple false alarms in a period
questions.explanation: Swinger shutdown automatically bypasses zones that alarm multiple times without user reset, preventing continuous false alarm calls.

questions.question: What is a recessed door contact?
options: A contact installed inside the door frame for concealment
questions.explanation: Recessed contacts are drilled into the door frame and door edge, making them hidden and more tamper-resistant than surface-mounted contacts.

questions.question: What is a shock sensor?
options: Sensor detecting vibration/impact from break-in attempts
questions.explanation: Shock (vibration) sensors detect impacts and vibrations from attempted forced entry on doors, windows, walls, or safes.

questions.question: What is takeover in alarm systems?
options: Using existing sensor wiring with a new panel/system
questions.explanation: Takeover involves installing a new alarm panel using existing sensor wiring and possibly sensors from a previous system, reducing installation cost.
